You won't be sorry if you watch "Red" before the other two films of the "3 Colors" trilogy -- which is what I did, not knowing any better -- but the end of the film will make a lot more sense if you see the films in chronological order. Kieslowski sprinkles some visual puns throughout the trilogy also that benefit from this approach.Many people believe "Red" to be slightly superior to the other two films, perhaps because it is the most uplifting or "life-affirming." It probably is those things. I still think "Blue" is the best, with "White" a bit better than "Red". In the first two films, the main characters undergo major changes themselves; in "Red" the major changes happen TO Valentine; she simply reacts to them. She's ultimately the same good, decent, kind-hearted person in the end that she was in the beginning; it is SHE who changes the judge from misanthrope to human being. The heroes in "White" and "Blue" certainly react to change as well, but it's their response to it and their characters' metamorphosis that constitutes the backbone of each film's respective plot.Which is just a long-winded way of saying: see all three films. You won't be disappointed, whichever order you choose!

reviews.review_title: Trois Couleurs: Rouge by Krzysztof Kieslowski
reviews.content: The theme brotherhood is one of the most fundamental ones, which is reflected in the poetry and in the philosophy; especially to see how between two people, who either knew each other for a long time or they never met each other before, would get a bond with each other. Some authors might describe the brotherhood between two people, would go far to be always close with each other, no matter how much distant they are with each other; other authors might describe the brotherhood between two people, would arrive to a certain point to be not anymore close with each other, where the first one tries to find a new contact to be in touch with and the second one tries to get distant from everything around. After Trois Couleurs: Bleu and Trois Couleurs: Blanc, the auteur filmmaker Krzysztof Kieslowski has arrived to the conclusion of the trilogy, by exploring the theme brotherhood; to connect it with the last French flag color, which is the red one that represents brotherhood. In 1994 came out Trois Couleurs: Rouge by Krzysztof Kieslowski with Irène Jacob and Jean-Louis Trintignant. The movie's plot: The model Valentine Dussaut (Irène Jacob) finds a dog in the streets, to lately bring back to the retired judge Joseph Kern (Jean-Louis Trintignant), who owns the animal. They would lately develop a strange bond with each other, not a romantic connection, but a bond to stay connected with each other. To arrive the last chapter of a trilogy, is usually difficult to develop a conclusion which would not be repetitive or if it would use elements to be not convincing enough. The movie worked well to be an interesting conclusion of the Three Colours Trilogy, which uses some interesting elements connected with the themes of the story; without using the same elements, which were already explored in Trois Couleurs: Bleu and Trois Couleurs: Blanc. The movie differently from the previous two chapters of the trilogy, is a much complete story of the trilogy; even it presents some moments which were unclear, including the reason of the main characters to take some actions. The production designer Claude Lenoir has created the settings, by showing how much the main characters are close with each other, since their first meeting; by seeing how much both of them needed a contact, which they were looking for a long time. Especially by using the red color to visually create, the spaces and objects around the settings, connected with themes of the movie. The cinematographer Piotr Sobocinski has captured, some of the essential frames, needed to create powerful images; by even get helped by the lightings, to create emotions which visually express the feelings of the main characters and how the story would move on. The editor Jacques Witta has elaborated a narration's rhythm, which gets clear how the movie would be told, from the beginning to the end; to find a way, where the main characters would encounter, the main ones of the previous chapters of the Three Colours Trilogy. The score by Zbigniew Preisner has been elaborated by creating musical notes, which would musically describe the emotions of the main characters and the themes of the movie; by being fused with the moments of the movie, needed to create some unexpected emotions. Irène Jacob did an excellent performance as Valentine Dussaut, a model who is busy with her job and get pressure by her boyfriend, who lives in London and wants her to be with him; once she would meet the retired judge Joseph Kern, she would develop a strange bond with him. Even there should have been more details, about how much does affect her emotionally the distance between her with her boyfriend and some of her closest friends; some details about her loneliness, to see how much has been changed, since her meetings with the retired judge; if she has any kind of wishes, to give a change on herself psychologically. Jean-Louis Trintignant did a well done performance as Joseph Kern, a retired judge who has a dog that was lost and lately found by Valentine; from their first meeting, they develop a bond with each other, not necessarily a romantic bond but a connection which they both were looking for a long time. Even there should have been more details about, if he has in once a similar connection with someone who was dear to him; if he notices some changes, in the way people connects with each other, from his time until the current days; some specific details if he sees more or less improvements, with the current judgers. Trois Couleurs: Rouge is an interesting conclusion of an important trilogy, which contains some unclear of the specific moments, as well as some unclear motivations of the main characters.

reviews.review_title: Powerful resolution, best in the series
reviews.content: Red is the best film in the three colours series as it manages, deftly, a fine balance between the moody tragedy and the comedic lightedness of White. On all aspects it is done just right, avoiding each extreme marvellously. For instance, a common complaint of Blue is that it is overly stylistic without any plot substance, while White has too much plot and too little grace and style. Red does it just right- we can see camera movement and colour use which has become a trademark of the director, while the plot of a flourishing friendship between a judge and a woman keeps us in mystery, entertains, then soothes us with a satisfying resolution. The directors intended the theme for red to be fraternity- on how everyone's lifes are connected- and with its pleasing resolution, we see this theme play out clearly and intelligently, more so than in the other 2 films. We follow an aspiring judge for no reason at all, until it is revealed to us in the end. My reservations with this film are deeply personal- don't let my rating of 9 affect you- I'd imagine this film is easily a 10 for many people. Ultimately, this film remains us how little each of us are, that our mindsets are parochial and narrow, and it is only with an omniscient narrators eye, which this film provides, that we can see how no man is an island entire of itself.
